Award.AwardTitle: Conference Proposal: Student and Junior Faculty Travel Support for International Symposium on Sustainable Systems and Technology (ISSST) 2016

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
1632975
Seager, Thomas P.

The International Symposium on Sustainable Systems and Technology (ISSST) will cover a spectrum of issues for assessing and managing products and services across their life cycle, as well as the design, management, and policy implications of sustainably engineered systems and technologies. The conference will have significant participation from students and young faculty members. The requested funds will help to expand the participation of students, underrepresented groups, and junior faculty from across the United States. Among others, three particular sessions planned for this year are (1) resilient infrastructure systems, (2) diverse photovoltaic stakeholder inputs and advancing life cycle analysis methods, and (3) approaches that bring together diverse groups and encourage high levels of participation.

The ISSST paradigm is that solutions to complex sustainability issues are achieved via trans-disciplinary approaches. At ISSST, cross-pollination of ideas among natural scientists, engineers, social scientists, industry representatives, and policy makers facilitates the development of a holistic understanding of sustainability applicable to engineered systems. All sessions will be live broadcasted on the ISSST Youtube channel, and authors will have open access to the publications on the digital journal, Figshare. Authors' research will be licensed, assigned a DOI, and indexed by Google Scholar and the Library of Congress.

POR.DRECONTENT:
With partial support from the National Science Foundation (NSF), over 150 scientists, students, engineers, and practitioners convened to share knowledge at the International Symposium for Sustainable Systems & Technologies (www.issst2016.net) in Phoenix AZ during May 2016.  The symposium featured workshops on resilient infrastructure systems, the environmental impact of emerging photovoltaic technologies, and the role of creativity in sustainability science and design.  The symposium also featured research presentations related to environmental life cycle assessment, materials flow analysis, sustainability policy, and alternative energy technologies.  NSF funding supported 40 junior faculty and graduate students with partial travel awards and recognition as 'ISSST Sustainability Scholars'.

Symposium presentations were live-streamed on YouTube to extend the impact of the conference and allow global participation, and resulted in six published journal articles in a special section of the journal Environmental Systems & Decisions.  Several students were recognized in the 'Best Poster Competition' sponsored by Earthshift Global, including Marcus Snell (Arizona State University, ASU), Sagar Gautam (University of Missouri), Hanjiro Ambrose (University California, Davis) and Robert Phillips (Northeastern University).

The theme of the symposium was sustainability leadership and featured keynote talks from Dr. Gary Dirks, Director of the Julie Ann Wrigley Global Institute for Sustainability at ASU and former  President of British Petroleum Asia-Pacific, Dr. Steve Schein, author of A New Psychology for Sustainability Leadership, and Dr. Thomas P Seager, President of the  the Sustainability Conoscente Network and Associate Professor of Sustainability at ASU, and others.
